awd_titl_txt: RUI:  A Phylogenomic Approach to Understanding the Symbiosis Between Acropyga Ants and Xenococcine Mealybugs
awd_abstract_narration:
A major question in evolutionary biology is how different kinds of organisms can form and maintain mutually beneficial relationships over long periods of time, often with conflicting self-interests. This project will use state-of-the-art techniques to study an insect agriculture system to understand the evolutionary bonds between Acropyga ants and mealybugs. Acropyga ants are herder ants that use mealybugs in a similar way humans use diary-cattle. The ants keep the mealybugs in their nests, place them on underground plant roots to feed, and then the ants feed on honeydew (fluid) the mealybugs excrete through specialized pores. By reconstructing the evolutionary relationships of the ants and mealybugs it will be investigated whether or not the two partners have influenced each other's species diversity over time. The ant - mealybug system is a powerful model system to contribute to a broader understanding of the evolution of mutualisms among species. This project will also provide research training in taxonomy and systematics to undergraduate and graduate students, engage K-12 teachers with training to improve K-12 science education, and contribute to scientific infrastructure through collections and publicly accessible websites (e.g., AntWeb).

The primary research goals of this study are twofold: 1) conduct phylogenomic studies of Acropyga ants and xenococcine mealybugs using genomics level data (ultraconserved elements) and 2) use the phylogenies to test for codiversification between lineages. The production of robust phylogenies using a phylogenomic approach to capture and sequence, using next-generation sequencing, ultraconserved elements from the two insect partners in this system will provide data at multiple evolutionary timescales. The vertical transmission of mealybugs across ant generations via trophophoresy and the high specificity of xenococcine species inhabiting ant nests both lead to the expectation of codiversification between the partners.  We will test three hypotheses: 1) weak partner fidelity (null); 2) diffuse-sense codiversification; and 3) strict-sense codiversification. We will utilize both permutation and event-based methods to test for significant levels of cospeciation between ant and mealybug phylogenies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A key question in evolutionary biology is how mutualistic relationships evolve and persist over millions of years. While theory suggests that mutualisms may devolve into parasitism over time, examples like fungus-farming ants show remarkable stability stretching back at least 60 million years. Ant agriculture provides a useful model for understanding the evolution of obligatory mutualism overall and may, in fact, offer insights into human agricultural history and practices. Herder ants are an understudied group of ant agriculturists who use sapsucking insects as a food source by collecting honeydew produced by the insects as a byproduct of sap-feeding. One such group of herder ants are Acropyga species that farm root mealybugs (Rhizoecidae and Xenococcidae). Acropyga queens engage in trophophoresy, carrying a pregnant root mealybug between their mandibles during their mating flights. This mealybug will be used to start a new herd of mealybugs in the new ant colony the queen has established. Current research suggests that controlling symbiont dispersal and reproduction is key to maintaining stable mutualisms. Trophophoresy has the potential to be an important method by which Acropyga ants control their root mealybug symbionts.

   Using phylogenomic techniques, this project generated ultraconserved elements (UCEs) sequence data of both Acropyga ants and their associated root mealybugs. With these data phylogenetic trees of both the ants and mealybugs were generated. Our data suggest that the symbiotic relationship between the ants and mealybugs has existed for around 35 million years. Further, it provides strong evidence of codiversification, that is the phylogenetic trees show similar branching patterns suggestive of a shared evolutionary history together. Furthermore, it shows that Acropyga originally evolved with one group of root mealybugs called Xenococcidae, but beginning around 15 million years made several independent movements onto another group of root mealybugs called Rhizoecidae, a group in which the majority of species are free-living and not obligatorily associated with ants. We also found strong evidence that once root mealybugs evolve with Acropyga they begin a series of convergent morphological features most notably becoming small and either round or pyriform in shape. Other important morphological changes in the mealybugs involve the loss of defensive structures such as wax pores and ostioles, which are glands used for reflexive bleeding to repulse potential predators. The loss of these defensive structures compared to their free-living relatives is suggestive they have become domesticated by the ants. This is one of the few non-human examples of an animal group domesticating another group of animals.

   Using symbiosis as the basis for various studies has allowed the project to support four masters-level graduate students at Towson University. In addition to graduate students, this project supported two postdoctoral fellows who learned new techniques in phylogenomics and codiversification analyses as part of their training. The project also benefited both pre-service and in-service middle school science teachers. Through a summer internship practicing middle school science teachers, participated in describing a new Acropyga ant species and took what they learned to create classroom activities based around the basics of species discovery and its importance to understanding and conserving biodiversity. From this internship material this project was incorporated into a science teacher course at Towson University where pre-service teachers learned about how scientific research works in general, and specifically how taxonomy and evolutionary biology are studied. They used this information to create lesson plans they would take to the classroom.
